speaker: RESIDENT
text: Hi, I’m one of the medicine residents. I know you just came up from the emergency department. Can you tell me in your own words what brought you in tonight?

speaker: PATIENT
text: My right-sided headache’s been worse for a few days, and the pain over the right side of my face is really bad. I also noticed new blisters on the right lower part of my face and more itching. I got dizzy and a little short of breath after dialysis this morning, so my doctor told me to come to the ER.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: You’ve had shingles involving that right eye and scalp before, with ongoing nerve pain there, correct? Any change in your vision from your usual baseline in the right eye?

speaker: PATIENT
text: Yes, I had shingles on the right side with my eye involved before, and the pain never really went away. My right eye has been bad since then, but it’s not worse than usual now.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: In the ER they told me your blood counts were a bit low and your kidney numbers were high, which is expected with your dialysis. Your potassium was also elevated, so they started treatment for that. We’ll continue to monitor your labs closely. Right now your blood pressure and temperature are at your usual baseline and you don’t have a fever.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. I know my kidneys are bad. I just feel worried about these blisters and the pain. Are you thinking the shingles is back?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Because of your history and the new right facial lesions, we are concerned about possible zoster reactivation, especially since your immune system is very weak from HIV. In the ER, Ophthalmology looked at your eyes and didn’t see any new dendritic lesions, and they recommended acyclovir eye ointment for a week. You also received an oral dose of acyclovir and IV morphine for pain there. We’ve started IV and oral acyclovir here as well while we wait for more tests.

speaker: PATIENT
text: They did put some ointment in my eyes downstairs and gave me something for pain. The pain is a little better now, but the itching is driving me crazy. I usually take hydroxyzine at home for that.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: We can restart hydroxyzine for your itching and also use topical treatments. I see you have a long-standing itchy rash on your arms and legs as well, which Dermatology later thought was eosinophilic folliculitis related to your HIV. We’ll have Dermatology see you and they may do skin biopsies to clarify what’s going on with both the chronic rash and the new facial lesions.

speaker: PATIENT
text: If they have to do biopsies, that’s fine. I just want to know what this rash is and stop the itching.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: You also mentioned your HIV medicines. You restarted HAART about two weeks ago with abacavir, atazanavir, ritonavir, and emtricitabine. We’ll continue those here, along with your prophylaxis with Bactrim three times a week and azithromycin weekly to prevent opportunistic infections.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Yes, they just restarted those pills a couple weeks ago. I try to take them like the bottles say, but it’s a lot to keep track of.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: We’ll help organize them while you’re here and make sure you leave with clear instructions. For tonight, we’ll keep you on the medicine floor, continue acyclovir, manage your pain and itching, and monitor your labs and heart rhythm, since you have a history of atrial fibrillation.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. I’ve had that irregular heartbeat before, but I don’t feel anything funny in my chest right now.

speaker: NURSE
text: I’m your nurse tonight. Your vital signs are stable—your blood pressure is in the 90s over 50s, which is your usual, and your oxygen is 100% on room air. I’ll bring your pain medicine and hydroxyzine now, and we’ll keep an eye on your heart monitor.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Thank you. I’d like something for the headache too if I can have it.

speaker: NURSE
text: You’re due for oxycodone now, and the doctor also ordered acetaminophen for headaches. I’ll give you the oxycodone first and see how you do.

speaker: PATIENT
text: That sounds good. The Percocet-type pills usually help some.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Good morning. I’m the attending on the medicine service. I’ve reviewed your labs and imaging so far. Your CT chest doesn’t show signs of PCP pneumonia, just some small granulomas and a ground-glass spot in the right lower lobe that could be from infection or aspiration, but nothing acute. Your oxygen levels and exam are reassuring.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So my lungs are okay? I get short of breath when I walk, but that’s been going on for years.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Yes, nothing new in the lungs. You’ve had exertional shortness of breath for years and prior workups showed only mild pulmonary hypertension. We’ll keep monitoring, but right now there’s no evidence of PCP or fluid overload on the CT.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Regarding your rash and facial pain, Dermatology and Infectious Disease will see you today. They may biopsy the skin on your arm and face to distinguish between zoster and other causes like eosinophilic dermatitis or drug reaction. We’ll continue IV acyclovir until we have more information.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. Will those biopsies hurt a lot?

speaker: CONSULT
text: Hi, we’re from Dermatology. We see the chronic itchy papules on your arms and legs and the ulcerations on your right cheek. Given your HIV and the high eosinophil count in your blood, this could be an eosinophilic dermatitis or drug reaction rather than active shingles. We’d like to do small punch biopsies from your left arm and right face under local anesthesia.

speaker: PATIENT
text: If it helps figure this out, go ahead. I just don’t want big scars on my face.

speaker: CONSULT
text: We’ve finished the biopsies—one from the left arm and one from the right cheek. You have a few sutures on the right side of your face now. We’ll send these to pathology. Early results will likely be back in a couple of days, and we’ll update you. For now, we agree with continuing acyclovir until we’re sure it’s not zoster.

speaker: PATIENT
text: All right. It’s sore but tolerable. How long will the stitches need to stay in?

speaker: CONSULT
text: The facial sutures should come out in about a week, and the arm sutures in about two weeks. We’ll make sure that’s in your discharge instructions.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: This morning’s labs show your potassium is still a bit high and your kidney numbers are up, which we expect before dialysis. Nephrology has arranged your usual hemodialysis session today, and they’ve ordered kayexalate as well. We’re also continuing your cinacalcet and sevelamer, and we doubled your sevelamer dose to help with high phosphate.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I usually get dialysis Monday, Wednesday, Friday, so that sounds right. I don’t like that kayexalate, but I’ll take it if I have to.

speaker: NURSE
text: We’re taking you down for dialysis now. Your blood pressure is a little low but similar to your usual. If you feel dizzy during dialysis, let the nurses there know right away.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I usually get lightheaded during dialysis. Sometimes they have to give me some saline.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: You’re back from dialysis. The team reports you had some low blood pressure during the run, but it improved with a small saline bolus. Your post-dialysis labs show your potassium and BUN have come down.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Yeah, I felt woozy for a bit, but I feel okay now. The headache is still there though.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: We’re still working up the headaches. Your CT head yesterday didn’t show any bleeding, stroke, or mass. Given your HIV and the worsening headaches with some photophobia, we’re planning a lumbar puncture tomorrow under fluoroscopic guidance to look for infections like meningitis or cryptococcus.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I’ve had headaches for a long time, but lately they’re more often and sometimes the light bothers me. If the spinal tap will help rule out infections, I’ll do it, but I’m nervous.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: That’s understandable. Radiology will use imaging to guide the needle, and they’ll collect some spinal fluid for tests. We’ll also give you something like lorazepam to help with anxiety during the procedure.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. I’d like something to calm me down for that.

speaker: CONSULT
text: We’re the Neuroradiology team. We’ll be doing your lumbar puncture now. We’ll numb the area with lidocaine and use fluoroscopy to guide the needle. If you feel any sharp pain or tingling, let us know.

speaker: PATIENT
text: All right. I’m still a bit scared, but I’m ready.

speaker: CONSULT
text: We’ve completed the lumbar puncture and collected clear spinal fluid. There were no complications. You may have some soreness in your lower back. Try to lie flat for a bit, and let the floor team know if you develop a severe positional headache.

speaker: PATIENT
text: My back feels a little sore, but otherwise I’m okay. I hope this tells you what’s causing the headaches.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Your spinal fluid results are back. The white cell count is very low, protein and glucose are normal, and the cryptococcal antigen is negative. Cultures and viral studies so far show no growth. This makes meningitis or other CNS infections very unlikely.

speaker: PATIENT
text: That’s a relief. So the headaches aren’t from an infection in my brain?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Correct. Between the normal CT head, the normal MRI brain, and the reassuring spinal fluid, we don’t see evidence of infection, bleeding, or mass. It may be a chronic headache disorder or related to your neuralgia. We’ll continue to treat the pain with oxycodone and, if needed, a combination medication with acetaminophen, caffeine, and butalbital.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I’ve tried a lot of headache medicines before without much luck, but the oxycodone does help some.

speaker: CONSULT
text: We’re back from Dermatology with your biopsy results. Both the left arm and right face biopsies show an ulcer with neutrophilic crust and a superficial lymphocytic infiltrate with eosinophils, consistent with a hypersensitivity or drug reaction with follicular accentuation. HSV and VZV stains are negative, and cultures from the tissue only grew coagulase-negative staph. Overall, this fits eosinophilic dermatitis or folliculitis rather than active zoster.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So it’s not shingles again? That’s good. What does that mean for treatment?

speaker: CONSULT
text: Right, we don’t see evidence of active shingles. We recommend stopping acyclovir now. For the rash, we’ll continue hydroxyzine for itching and start mupirocin cream twice daily on the facial lesions. We don’t think you need systemic antibiotics like cephalexin for impetigo at this point.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. I’m glad I don’t need more IV antivirals. The cream and the itch pills sound fine.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: This morning your facial ulcerations and pustules look much better, and the chronic prurigo on your legs is healing. Your pain is improved but still present. We’ll continue hydroxyzine, mupirocin, and your neuropathic pain medicine desipramine, and keep oxycodone-acetaminophen as needed.

speaker: PATIENT
text: The rash does look less angry, and the itching is a bit better. The face still hurts, but not as bad as when I came in.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Your blood counts remain low but stable—white cells around 2.5 to 3.5, hemoglobin around 10 to 11, and platelets just over 100. Coagulation tests are normal, and you haven’t had any bleeding. This is likely from HIV-related bone marrow suppression and chronic disease. We’ll continue to monitor but don’t need transfusions.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I’ve been told my counts are low before. As long as I’m not bleeding, I’m okay with not getting blood.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: We repeated your basic labs today. Your creatinine is again elevated before dialysis, and your BUN and phosphate are up, but your potassium is in the mid-4s. We’ll continue your Monday–Wednesday–Friday dialysis schedule and the higher sevelamer dose. Your bicarbonate and anion gap are acceptable.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Dialysis always makes me tired, but I know I need it. I’m glad the potassium isn’t as high now.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Your MRI brain from this evening is normal—no infarct, hemorrhage, or abnormal signal. That, along with the CT and LP, really reassures us there’s no structural or infectious cause for the headaches. We’ll keep managing them symptomatically.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Good to know. The headaches are still there but at least I know it’s not something like a tumor or bleeding.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: We’re getting close to sending you home. Your vital signs are at your baseline—blood pressure in the mid-90s over 50–60s, heart rate 80–90, afebrile, and oxygen saturation 100% on room air. Your facial lesions are healing, the rash and itching are improved, and your headaches and facial pain are better controlled with your current regimen.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I do feel better than when I came in. The itching is much less, and the face doesn’t hurt as much, though I still have some pain.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: For discharge, we’ll send you home with your HAART regimen—abacavir, atazanavir, ritonavir, and emtricitabine—as well as Bactrim three times a week and azithromycin weekly. You’ll continue cinacalcet and sevelamer for your kidneys, aspirin for your atrial fibrillation, desipramine for neuropathic pain, hydroxyzine as needed for itching, oxycodone-acetaminophen for pain, and mupirocin cream for the facial rash.

speaker: PATIENT
text: That’s a lot of medicines, but I’ll do my best. Will someone go over the schedule with me before I leave?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Yes, we’ll give you a written list and review it with you. We’ve also arranged follow-up with your HIV doctor and instructions for suture removal—face sutures in about one week and arm sutures in about two weeks. You’ll continue your regular outpatient dialysis schedule as well.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. I’ll make sure to go to those appointments and dialysis. Thank you all for taking care of me.

speaker: NURSE
text: Your discharge paperwork is ready. You’re going home with visiting services, and transport will be here shortly. I’ve gone over your medications and when to call your doctors. Do you have any last questions before you leave?

speaker: PATIENT
text: No, I think I’m all set. I just want to get home and rest.
